The protocol signed the same day establishes that "the government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics will grant an amnesty to all Polish citizens who are currently deprived of their liberty on the territory of the USSR, either as prisoners of war or for other reasons. » Prime Minister of the Polish Government in exile. The agreement stipulates, among other things, that the Soviet Union recognizes the futility of the German-Soviet treaties relating to the territorial changes of Poland and that it gives its consent to the constitution on its territory of a Polish army under Polish command designated by the government of the Republic of Poland. The protocol signed the same day establishes that "the government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics will grant an amnesty to all Polish citizens who are currently deprived of their liberty on the territory of the USSR, either as prisoners of war or for other reasons. » The agreement stipulates, among other things, that the Soviet Union recognizes the futility of the German-Soviet treaties relating to the territorial changes of Poland and that it gives its consent to the constitution on its territory of a Polish army under Polish command designated by the government of the Republic of Poland. The protocol signed the same day establishes that "the government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics will grant an amnesty to all Polish citizens who are currently deprived of their liberty on the territory of the USSR, either as prisoners of war or for other reasons. » The agreement stipulates, among other things, that the Soviet Union recognizes the futility of the German-Soviet treaties relating to the territorial changes of Poland and that it gives its consent to the constitution on its territory of a Polish army under Polish command designated by the government of the Republic of Poland. The protocol signed the same day establishes that "the government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics will grant an amnesty to all Polish citizens who are currently deprived of their liberty on the territory of the USSR, either as prisoners of war or for other reasons. » The protocol signed the same day establishes that "the government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics will grant an amnesty to all Polish citizens who are currently deprived of their liberty on the territory of the USSR, either as prisoners of war or for other reasons. » The protocol signed the same day establishes that "the government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics will grant an amnesty to all Polish citizens who are currently deprived of their liberty on the territory of the USSR, either as prisoners of war or for other reasons. »

随即，在莫斯科险恶的卢比扬卡监狱中，被关押在那里的波兰将军弗拉迪斯拉夫·安德斯被从牢房中带出，带到贝利亚专员的办公室。安德斯将军在他的回忆录《流放的军队》中描述了这次采访。他详细解释了他如何在政委布置豪华的办公室里会见贝利亚和他的副手梅尔库洛夫，以及后者如何告诉他波兰当局在征得苏联政府同意后任命他为即将成立的新波兰军队的指挥官。被形成。

Immediately, in the sinister Lubyanka prison in Moscow, the Polish general Wladislav Anders, who was detained there, was taken from his cell and taken to Commissioner Beria's office. General Anders describes this interview in his memoir An Army in Exile . He explains in detail how he meets Beria and his deputy Merkulov in the commissar's luxuriously furnished office and how the latter tells him that the Polish authorities have appointed him, with the agreement of the Soviet government, commander of the new Polish army which is about to be formed.

几天后，几位波兰高级军官拜访了安德斯将军在莫斯科的家，他们是苏联的同情者，住在苏联首都附近的“欢乐别墅”里。他们在谈话中指出，科泽尔斯克、斯塔罗别尔斯克和奥斯塔什科夫三个战俘营中聚集着1.5万名波兰官兵。这些人对于重建波兰军队很有用。安德斯将军简要了解到，军官们在探望他之前，与负责这些营地的贝利亚会面，贝利亚现在有义务释放所有战俘。但是，尽管苏联与波兰达成协议，拉夫连季·贝利亚仍计划建立一支由波兰人组成的军队，

A few days later, General Anders was visited at his house in Moscow by several senior Polish officers who, as Soviet sympathizers, lived near the Soviet capital in the “Villa of Delights”. They point out during the conversation that 15,000 Polish officers and soldiers are assembled in the three prison camps of Kozelsk, Starobelsk and Ostashkov. These men could be of great use in reconstituting the Polish army. General Anders learns briefly that the officers, before visiting him, had a meeting with Beria who, being responsible for these camps, is now obliged to release all the prisoners of war. But, despite the Soviet-Polish agreement, Lavrenty Beria planned the creation of an army made up of Poles,

正是出于这个目的，他才从“欢喜别墅”中带来了一行人的领导。当他们告诉他科泽尔斯克、奥斯塔什科夫和斯塔罗别尔斯克军营中有大量现役军官，可以为新军队提供干部时，贝利亚回避地回答说：“好吧！列出它们，但剩下的不多了，因为我们犯了一个大错误。出席会议的贝利亚副手梅尔库洛夫证实了上级的话：“不，不是那些。” 我们对他们犯了一个大错误。»

It was with this intention that he brought the leaders of the group from the “Villa of Delights”. When they told him of the large number of officers available for active service in the camps of Kozelsk, Ostashkov and Starobelsk, who could provide cadres for the new army, Beria replied evasively: “Well! list them, but there aren't many left because we made a big mistake . And Merkulov, Beria's deputy who was present at the meeting, confirmed his superior's words: "No, not those." We made a big mistake with them. »

这个神秘的答案可能暴露了贝利亚对于接受俄罗斯领土上强大的外国军队的犹豫。当时，还没有人知道卡廷森林和塞利格湖大屠杀。

This enigmatic answer could betray Beria's hesitation to accept a powerful foreign army on Russian soil. At that time, no one yet knew about the Katyn Forest and Lake Seliger massacres.

纳粹的入侵正在以惊人的速度发展。九月，德军进入顿巴斯。几周之内，他们占领了奥廖尔、图拉、维亚济马、罗斯托夫、卡卢加、敖德萨、塔甘罗格和哈尔科夫八个大城市，并围攻莫斯科。这些轻松的胜利与其说是因为德国士兵相对于俄罗斯人的优势，不如说是因为红军的士气接近于零。纳粹的宣传比其他任何事情都更成功。他们的野战无线电和扩音器日夜用俄语广播，要求苏联士兵站到他们一边。他们向他们许诺最好的条件、美味的食物和自由，让他们摆脱斯大林和贝利亚等嗜血暴君及其监狱的束缚，他们的强迫劳动营和他们造成的苦难。俄罗斯士兵记得土地集体化期间大规模驱逐农民，记得数十万俄罗斯工人被流放到西伯利亚的矿井，以及内务人民委员部特种部队在战争期间所发挥的作用。芬兰的战争，请用仁慈的耳朵聆听这种宣传。红军的排、部队、甚至整个团带着他们的装备、大炮、坦克和机枪穿越前线，同时也没有忘记他们的旗帜。他们向敌人投降，就像向救世主投降一样，军乐队演奏着欢快的乐曲。那些还记得数十万俄罗斯工人在西伯利亚矿井中流亡的人，以及内务人民委员部特种部队在芬兰战争中所扮演的角色，用仁慈的耳朵聆听着这种宣传。红军的排、部队、甚至整个团带着他们的装备、大炮、坦克和机枪穿越前线，同时也没有忘记他们的旗帜。他们向敌人投降，就像向救世主投降一样，军乐队演奏着欢快的乐曲。那些还记得数十万俄罗斯工人在西伯利亚矿井中流亡的人，以及内务人民委员部特种部队在芬兰战争中所扮演的角色，用仁慈的耳朵聆听着这种宣传。红军的排、部队、甚至整个团带着他们的装备、大炮、坦克和机枪穿越前线，同时也没有忘记他们的旗帜。他们向敌人投降，就像向救世主投降一样，军乐队演奏着欢快的乐曲。甚至红军的整个团都带着装备、大炮、坦克和机枪穿越前线，也没有忘记他们的旗帜。他们向敌人投降，就像向救世主投降一样，军乐队演奏着欢快的乐曲。甚至红军的整个团都带着装备、大炮、坦克和机枪穿越前线，也没有忘记他们的旗帜。他们向敌人投降，就像向救世主投降一样，军乐队演奏着欢快的乐曲。

The Nazi invasion is developing at a formidable speed. In September, the Germans enter the Donbas. In a few weeks, they seize eight large cities Orel, Tula, Viazma, Rostov, Kalouga, Odessa, Taganrog and Kharkov and lay siege to Moscow. These easy victories are due less to the superiority of the German soldiers over the Russians than to the morale of the Red Army, which is close to zero. Nazi propaganda is more successful than anything else. Their field radios and loudspeakers broadcast calls in Russian night and day asking Soviet soldiers to come over to their side. They promise them the best conditions, good food and freedom from those bloodthirsty tyrants Stalin and Beria with their prisons, their forced labor camps and the misery they create. The Russian soldiers, who remember the mass deportations of peasants during the collectivization of the land, who remember the exile of hundreds of thousands of Russian workers in the mines of Siberia, as well as the role played by the special troops of the NKVD during the war in Finland, listen to this propaganda with a benevolent ear. Platoons, units, even whole regiments of the Red Army cross the front lines with their equipment, their artillery, their tanks and their machine guns without forgetting their flags. They surrender to the enemy as to a savior while military bands play cheerful tunes. who remember the exile of hundreds of thousands of Russian workers in the mines of Siberia, as well as the role played by the special troops of the NKVD during the war in Finland, listen to this propaganda with a benevolent ear. Platoons, units, even whole regiments of the Red Army cross the front lines with their equipment, their artillery, their tanks and their machine guns without forgetting their flags. They surrender to the enemy as to a savior while military bands play cheerful tunes. who remember the exile of hundreds of thousands of Russian workers in the mines of Siberia, as well as the role played by the special troops of the NKVD during the war in Finland, listen to this propaganda with a benevolent ear. Platoons, units, even whole regiments of the Red Army cross the front lines with their equipment, their artillery, their tanks and their machine guns without forgetting their flags. They surrender to the enemy as to a savior while military bands play cheerful tunes. even whole regiments of the Red Army cross the front lines with their equipment, their artillery, their tanks and their machine guns without forgetting their flags. They surrender to the enemy as to a savior while military bands play cheerful tunes. even whole regiments of the Red Army cross the front lines with their equipment, their artillery, their tanks and their machine guns without forgetting their flags. They surrender to the enemy as to a savior while military bands play cheerful tunes.

形势对苏联来说变成了灾难。红军必须千方百计、尽快整顿。这项任务落到了国家安全专员拉夫连蒂·贝利亚的肩上。他的人生迎来了转折点。如果他失败了，他将被成群的监狱和劳改营幸存者砍成碎片，否则他将被跟随胜利的纳粹军队的盖世太保枪杀。

The situation turns to the disaster for the Soviet Union. The Red Army must be reorganized by all means and as quickly as possible. This task falls to Lavrenti Beria, Commissioner for State Security. His life comes to a turning point. If he fails, he will be cut to pieces by the hordes of prison and labor camp survivors, or he will be shot by the Gestapo following the victorious Nazi army.

贝利亚要求斯大林向特种部队调拨更多武器和部队。他需要它来实现与他在芬兰所寻求的目标不同的目标。他需要更多的士兵来加强对数百个集中营的看守，以防止囚犯任何反抗的企图。在整个苏联领土上守卫监狱的内务人民委员部部队指挥官接到命令，在疏散前一天晚上将囚犯从牢房中转移出来，将他们围困在监狱院子里，并用机关枪处决他们。

Beria asks Stalin to transfer more weapons and troops to the special forces. He needs it to achieve a different goal than he was looking for in Finland. He needs more soldiers to reinforce the guard in the hundreds of concentration camps, in order to prevent any attempt of revolt on the part of the prisoners. Commanders of NKVD units guarding prisons throughout Soviet territory are ordered to remove inmates from their cells the night before evacuation, round them up in the prison yard and execute them with the machine gun.

斯大林大元帅和贝利亚政委决定对所有无论自愿与否，即使被德国人包围并压倒的苏联士兵，也要毫不留情地向敌人投降。根据贝利亚的建议，斯大林发布的新公告在红军各支队面前宣读。然而，这一次，总司令并没有诉诸部下的爱国情感。他只是简短地宣布，任何被俘的士兵，即使受伤，也将被视为自动投降，当被重新俘虏时，将被视为叛徒和逃兵。对他的惩罚将是送上军事法庭并由内务人民委员部排处决。除了，

Generalissimo Stalin and Commissar Beria decide to be ruthless towards all Soviet soldiers who, voluntarily or not, even if surrounded and overwhelmed by the Germans, surrender to the enemy. On a suggestion of Beria, a new proclamation emanating from Stalin is read in front of each detachment of the Red Army. This time, however, the commander-in-chief does not appeal to the patriotic feelings of his subordinates. He merely announces curtly that any soldier taken prisoner, even if wounded, will be considered to surrender voluntarily to the enemy and, when recaptured, will be treated as a traitor and a deserter. Court-martial and execution by an NKVD platoon will be his punishment. Besides,

这项立即生效的命令对斯大林的儿子雅科夫也不例外，他从伏龙芝军事学院毕业后，在德国袭击他的国家的第二天就前往前线。他在前线作战时受伤，被俘虏。被捕的消息一传到克里姆林宫，贝利亚就高兴地得到了斯大林的许可，向雅科夫的妻子尤利娅宣布了新措施。他逮捕了她，未经审判就判处她三年监禁，尽管她是斯大林孙女、三岁孩子古利亚的唯一抚养者。贝利亚轻易地就获得了逮捕她的许可，因为她是犹太人，仅此一点就足以让斯大林恨她。对于贝利亚来说，这名女子的被捕是一次甜蜜而秘密的胜利，他总是因为给别人带来不幸而感到特别高兴。而这一次，拉夫连季出击的不仅是尤利娅，还有斯大林的儿子。如果贝利亚能够割断约瑟夫·斯大林的喉咙，他在书中和演讲中如此坚持地颂扬他，他肯定会更加恶毒地这样做。但那一刻还没有到来。内政和国家安全专员决定等待这个机会。他在书中和演讲中如此坚持地颂扬，他肯定会以更加积极的态度这样做。但那一刻还没有到来。内政和国家安全专员决定等待这个机会。他在书中和演讲中如此坚持地颂扬，他肯定会以更加积极的态度这样做。但那一刻还没有到来。内政和国家安全专员决定等待这个机会。

This order, effective immediately, makes no exception for Stalin's own son, Yakov, who, after graduating from the Frunze military academy, left for the front the very day after the Germany attacked his country. Wounded while fighting in the front line, he was taken prisoner. As soon as the news of his capture reaches the Kremlin, Beria happily receives Stalin's permission to announce the new measure to Yulia, Yakov's wife. He has her arrested and sentenced without trial to three years in prison despite the fact that she is the sole support of a three-year-old child, Goulia, Stalin's granddaughter. Beria easily obtains permission to arrest her because she is Jewish and that alone is enough for Stalin to hate her. The arrest of this woman constitutes a sweet and secret triumph for Beria who always feels a particular joy in causing someone's misfortune. And this time it is not only Yulia, but also Stalin's son that Lavrenti strikes a blow. If Beria could slit the throat of Joseph Stalin, whom he glorifies so insistently in his book and in his speeches, he would certainly do it with even more spite. But that moment has not yet arrived. The Commissioner for Home Affairs and State Security decides to wait for this chance. that he glorifies with so much insistence in his book and in his speeches, he would certainly do so with even more aggressiveness. But that moment has not yet arrived. The Commissioner for Home Affairs and State Security decides to wait for this chance. that he glorifies with so much insistence in his book and in his speeches, he would certainly do so with even more aggressiveness. But that moment has not yet arrived. The Commissioner for Home Affairs and State Security decides to wait for this chance.

内务人民委员部排现在比以往任何时候都更加忙碌，因为他们必须追捕被敌人俘虏的俄罗斯士兵。数千名被监禁官兵的父母和子女被捕，所有财产被没收。贝利亚在他的政府中设立了一个新部门，旨在维护红军的士气。他任命他的助手维克多·阿巴库莫夫（Victor Abakumov）担任该部门的负责人。这种新生物的名字是 SMERCH，是两个俄语单词smert chpionam的缩写，“间谍之死”。然而，反情报在 SMERCH 中仅扮演次要角色。SMERCH 的主要职能是射杀撤退的俄罗斯士兵，处决那些被重新抓获的士兵，并通过在每个部队建立特工网络来监督军队成员的政治倾向。根据贝利亚本人制定的非常详细的指示，陆军、海军和空军的每个支队都被指派了一名 SMERCH 军官。该官员必须拥有各级线人。最轻微的谴责，即使未经证实，也足以导致逮捕和驱逐到劳改营，甚至被处决。

The NKVD platoons are busier than ever now that they have to pursue any Russian soldier captured by the enemy. Thousands of parents and children of imprisoned officers and soldiers are arrested, while all their property is confiscated. Beria creates a new department in his administration with the aim of looking after the morale of the Red Army. He places his assistant Victor Abakumov at the head of this department. The name of this new organism is SMERCH, an abbreviation of the two Russian words smert chpionam, "death to spies". Counterintelligence, however, plays only a minor role in SMERCH. SMERCH's main function is to shoot retreating Russian soldiers, execute those who have been recaptured, and oversee the political orientation of members of the military by setting up a network of agents in each unit. Following very detailed instructions developed by Beria himself, a SMERCH officer is assigned to each detachment of the army, navy and air force. This officer must have informants of all ranks. The smallest denunciation, even unproven, is enough to cause arrest and deportation to a forced labor camp or even execution.

苏雷特警察团免于前线战斗，致力于将伏尔加德国定居者的整个村庄驱逐到最北的村庄，这些定居者从苏联时代起就在萨拉托夫地区生活了几代人。伟大的凯瑟琳。现在这些人被迫背井离乡，丈夫与妻子分离，父母与孩子分离，并被送往苏联的另一边。贝利亚相信，这些仍然忠于新教和德语的人可以在敌人逼近他们的社区时组成第五纵队。因此，国家安全委员决定将他们转移到劳教所并用铁丝网42关押。

The police regiments of the Surete, exempted from fighting in the front line, are dedicated to the deportation to the far north of entire villages of Volga German settlers, who have lived for several generations, in the Saratov region, exactly since the era of the great Catherine. Now these people are uprooted from their homes, husbands are separated from their wives, parents from their children and transported to the other side of the Soviet Union. Beria believes that these people, who have remained faithful to the Protestant religion and the German language, can form a fifth column when the enemy approaches their communities. The State Security Commissioner therefore decides to transfer them to forced labor camps and keep them behind barbed wire 42 .

然而，所有这些预防措施都未能阻止德国人的胜利进程。他们的军队正在占领一座又一座俄罗斯城市。

All these precautions, however, failed to stop the victorious progression of the Germans. Their armies are capturing one Russian city after another.

1941年11月，德军围攻列宁格勒，占领莫斯科地区的两个城镇：克莱恩和伊斯特拉。后者距莫斯科仅二十五公里。

In November 1941, the Germans besieged Leningrad, and took two towns in the Moscow region: Kline and Istra. The latter is only twenty-five kilometers from Moscow.

苏联政府仓促撤离首都，避难伏尔加河中游左岸小镇古比雪夫。在总部所在的莫斯科的戒备森严的避难所里，只剩下“五巨头”：斯大林和四位政治家莫洛托夫、马林科夫、伏罗希洛夫和贝利亚。

The Soviet government hastily evacuated the capital and took refuge in Kuybyshev, a town on the left bank of the middle Volga. In the fortified shelters of Moscow, where the headquarters is located, only the “big five” remain: Stalin and four statesmen Molotov, Malenkov, Voroshilov and Beria.

贝利亚的办公室现在位于捷尔任斯基街 2 号地下室的防空洞内，贝利亚和一些合作者正忙着收集内务人民委员部的档案，烧毁所有警察档案和文件。以莫斯科为例。然后贝利亚就会试图逃跑。

In his office, now housed in an air-raid shelter in the basement of number 2 Dzerzhinsky Street, Beria and a handful of collaborators are busy gathering the archives of the NKVD to burn all the police files and documents. secret Soviet in case the Germans take Moscow. Then Beria would try to run away.

红军通过浴血奋战成功阻止德军向首都进军。这种英雄主义与其说是SMERCH行动的结果，不如说是希特勒疯狂愚蠢的结果，他没有遵守给予战俘自由和良好生活条件的承诺。相反，他命令党卫军和盖世太保部队用机关枪、毒气或电击集体杀死俄罗斯人。在德国的俄罗斯战俘也死于饥饿：他们被拒绝获得面包和各种食物。面对这样的命运，红军战士们为了保全自己的生命而战斗到底。没有必要让安全部队监视他们以将他们推向前线。与此同时，在德国战线后方的城镇和乡村，俄罗斯游击队自发地组织起来，在深厚的爱国主义的推动下，开展了一场大规模的秘密运动。这支军队由各个年龄段的士兵组成，从刚刚走出童年的男孩和女孩，到四分之一个世纪前参加过第一次世界大战的退伍军人。

The Red Army manages to prevent the progression of the Germans towards the capital by delivering bloody battles. This heroism results less from the action of SMERCH than from the mad stupidity of Hitler who did not keep his promise to grant freedom and good living conditions to prisoners of war. On the contrary, he orders the SS and the Gestapo troopsto kill the Russians en masse with machine guns, poison gas or electrocution. The Russian prisoners of war in Germany also died of starvation: they were refused bread and all kinds of food. Faced with such a destiny, the men of the Red Army fight to the bitter end to save their own lives. It is not necessary to have them watched by the Security troops to push them towards the front. Simultaneously, behind the German lines, in the towns and villages, the Russian partisans spontaneously organized themselves into a vast clandestine movement animated by a deep patriotism. This army is made up of soldiers of all ages, from boys and girls barely out of childhood to veterans who fought in the First World War a quarter of a century earlier.

尽管损失惨重，俄罗斯人还是成功保卫了莫斯科。纳粹的进攻被击退，首都落入德国人手中的危险也消失了。

Despite gigantic losses, the Russians successfully defend Moscow. The Nazi attack is repelled and the danger of seeing the capital fall into German hands vanishes.

在英国的帮助下，除了向苏联提供大量粮食、弹药和舰船、飞机等各类武器外，还在利比亚西部沙漠发动攻势，战局发生了变化，红军开始了反攻。反击。

With the help of Great Britain which, in addition to supplying the USSR with large quantities of food, ammunition and weapons of all kinds including ships and planes, launched an offensive in the Libyan western desert, the war changes face and the Red Army begins a counter-attack.

1941年底，战争形势发生了重大变化。在一个特别严酷的冬天——人们称之为“冬天将军”——的持续下，俄罗斯游击队和苏联士兵在愤怒的战斗中重新夺回了罗斯托夫市。莫斯科的反攻开始了。他们还解放了几个城市、小镇和重要的前哨基地。这些胜利的一部分仍然归功于贝利亚军队，他们装备了机枪，将正规部队推入战斗。拉夫连季再次执行斯大林对红军的最后命令——“我们不会退缩！” ——带着盲目顺从的下属的热情。一旦城镇或村庄被夺回，内务人民委员部部队就会进入其中。它逮捕任何与敌人有过接触的人或 懂得几句德语，也许能和他交流。来自邻居的毫无根据的告发，为逮捕被告发者提供了充分的理由，而被告发者则被殴打至牙齿全部脱落。这些人被分批驱逐到西伯利亚，每批两百人。任何与德国士兵发生关系的年轻俄罗斯女孩都会根据贝利亚向其部队发出的个人命令被枪杀。

Towards the end of 1941, the turn of the war changed significantly. Sustained by a particularly severe winter – people speak of “General Winter” – the Russian partisans and the Soviet soldiers, who are fighting with rage, retake the city of Rostov. Moscow's counter-offensive begins. They also liberated several cities, small towns and important outposts. A part of these victories is still due to the troops of Beria who, armed with machine guns, push the regular units into battle. Once again, Lavrenty enforces Stalin's last order to the Red Army – "we don't back down!" – with the zeal of a blindly submissive subordinate. As soon as a town or village is recaptured, an NKVD unit enters it. It arrests anyone who has had contact with the enemy or who, knowing a few words of German, may have communicated with him. An unfounded denunciation, emanating from a neighbor, provides sufficient reason for the arrest of the denounced person who is beaten until all his teeth are lost. These people are deported to Siberia in batches of two hundred. Any young Russian girl who has had relations with a German soldier is shot in application of a personal order from Beria to his troops.

由贝利亚副手维克多·阿巴库莫夫指挥的安全部队和 SMERCH 部队仍然牢牢控制着苏联军队。拉夫伦蒂和他的部下不再担心被胜利的盖世太保或劳改营中解放的群众消灭。

The Sûreté as well as the SMERCH units, commanded by Victor Abakumov, Beria's deputy, still held the Soviet forces in their iron grip. Lavrenti and his men no longer fear being exterminated themselves by a victorious Gestapo or by the liberated masses of the labor camps.

内务人民委员部的排也将德国囚犯带到遥远的北方。在俄罗斯的严冬里，贝利亚政委命令脱掉被俘士兵的制服和鞋子，只保留轻便的棉质衬衫、裤子和袜子。然后，在配备机枪的内务人民委员部人员的护卫下，货运列车的敞篷车厢将他们送往西伯利亚。

NKVD platoons also lead German prisoners to the far north. In the dead of Russian winter, Commissar Beria orders captured soldiers to be stripped of their uniforms and shoes and to keep only their light cotton shirts, trousers and socks. Then, guarded by NKVD men armed with machine guns, open carriages of freight trains take them to Siberia .

由于开往前线的部队、枪支弹药的军事运输享有优先权，满载战俘的敞篷列车停在路边，在夜间等待数小时。尽管有延误，但没有向囚犯分发额外的食物。黎明时分，整批囚犯不再需要被送往目的地：他们已经死亡或病得很重。我们以一种奇怪的方式摆脱它。当火车穿过草原或雪林时，它就会停下来。守卫将尸体扔在地上，并用桶水浇在他们身上，尸体立即变成了冰块。拉夫连季·贝利亚（Lavrenty Beria），红色秘密警察局长，斯大林最好的弟子之一，另一面海因里希·希姆莱，盖世太保头子，希特勒最好的弟子之一。难怪斯大林心情好的时候会称贝利亚为“我的希姆莱”。此外，不久前，无论好坏，斯大林和希特勒都是最好的盟友。

As the military transports of troops, guns and ammunition bound for the front enjoy priority, the open trains loaded with prisoners of war, stopped on the side, wait for hours, at night. Despite the delays, no additional food is distributed to the prisoners. At dawn, whole batches of prisoners no longer need to be taken to their destination: they are dead or very seriously ill. We get rid of it in a curious way. When the train crosses steppes or snowy forests, it stops. The guards throw the bodies to the ground and pour buckets of water over them, instantly turning the corpses into blocks of ice. Lavrenty Beria, chief of the red secret police and one of Stalin's best disciples,alter ego Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo and one of Hitler's best disciples. No wonder Stalin, when he was in a good mood, called Beria "my Himmler." Besides, shortly before, Stalin and Hitler were the best allies, for better or for worse.

战争越进展，贝利亚就越发现自己卷入了大政治，而他对警察局长的正常工作也投入得越少。每天开会的国防委员会必须解决两个最重要的问题。一是需要在遥远的北方维持200万士兵以应对日军可能的进攻。如果作为轴心国伙伴的日本决定履行对希特勒的承诺并帮助他在西伯利亚打击苏联，那么法西斯集团对苏联的胜利是板上钉钉的。然而，如果日本政府弃权，驻扎在西伯利亚的苏联军队可能会被转移到增援红军的欧洲战线。

The more the war progresses, the more Beria finds himself engaged in big politics and the less he devotes himself to his normal job as chief of police. The Defense Committee, which meets daily, must solve two problems of the utmost importance. One is the need to maintain two million men in the far north to meet a possible attack from the Japanese. If, as an Axis partner, Japan decides to fulfill its commitments to Hitler and help him by striking the USSR in Siberia, the victory of the fascist bloc over the Soviet Union is more than certain. However, if the Japanese government abstains, the Soviet troops stationed in Siberia could be moved to reinforce the European front of the Red Army.

要讨论的第二点涉及美国的参战，仅此一项就可能抵消德国对俄罗斯的优势。此时，美国满足于向苏联、英国和法国输送战争物资。

The second point to be discussed concerns the entry into the war of the United States, which alone is likely to counterbalance the superiority of Germany over Russia. At this time, the United States is content to deliver war material to the Soviet Union, Great Britain and France.

克里姆林宫国防委​​员会得出的结论是，美国参战对苏联来说是生死攸关的问题，只有通过精心准备的挑衅才能实现。

The Kremlin Defense Committee comes to the conclusion that US entry into the war is a matter of life or death for the USSR and can only be achieved through a carefully prepared provocation.

这两项任务的实现主要取决于贝利亚。

The realization of these two missions depends primarily on Beria.

贝利亚在日本拥有一个组织严密的网络，由主要红色间谍理查德·佐尔格博士领导。这位德国共产党人的祖父阿道夫·佐尔格 (Adolf Sorge) 是卡尔·马克思 (Karl Marx) 的私人秘书44，拥有政治学博士学位，曾担任《法兰克福报》的通讯员在远东。他是纳粹党成员，也是纳粹宣传部长约瑟夫·戈培尔的私人朋友，戈培尔将他介绍给元首。当理查德·佐尔格被派往日本时，他享有最大的信心。在东京，他成为德国大使馆的常客，也是大使赫伯特·冯·德克森博士的好朋友。后来，当纳粹空军将军尤金·奥特接替冯·德克森时，理查德·佐尔格的朋友、新任大使任命佐尔格担任大使馆新闻秘书。佐尔格是最后一个被怀疑是苏联间谍的人。

Beria has a well-organized network in Japan led by the main red spy, Doctor Richard Sorge. This German communist, whose grandfather, Adolf Sorge, was private secretary to Karl Marx 44 , has a doctorate in political science and worked as a correspondent for the Frankfurter Zeitungin the Far East. He is a member of the Nazi Party and a personal friend of Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Nazi Propaganda, who introduced him to the Führer. Richard Sorge enjoys the utmost confidence when he is sent to Japan. In Tokyo, he became a regular at the German embassy and an excellent friend of the ambassador, Doctor Herbert von Dirksen. Later, when Nazi Air Force General Eugen Ott replaced von Dirksen, the new ambassador, a friend of Richard Sorge, appointed Sorge to the position of embassy press secretary. Sorge is the last man to be suspected of being a Soviet spy.

在贝利亚的资助下，佐尔格医生立即组建了一个由特别有资格的人组成的圈子。他招募了一位年轻的日本教师兼记者尾崎保纯（Hozumi Ozaki）和一位日本艺术家宫城洋德（Yotoku Miyagi）。两人都属于东京的上流社会。通过他们，佐尔格可以接触到日本政府成员，甚至首相近卫文郎亲王。佐尔格医生从他位于东京郊区的别墅将信息传输给贝利亚，他在那里拥有一个由富商马克斯·克劳森操作的秘密无线电发射器。这群间谍提供了宝贵的情报。1941 年 10 月 15 日，佐尔格博士向莫斯科发出暗语，宣布日本不会攻击苏联。

Provided with money by Beria, Doctor Sorge immediately constitutes a circle of particularly qualified men. He recruits a young Japanese teacher and journalist, Hozumi Ozaki, and a Japanese artist, Yotoku Miyagi. Both belong to the good society of Tokyo. Through them, Sorge can reach members of the Japanese government and even the Prime Minister, Prince Fuminaro Konoye. Doctor Sorge transmits his information to Beria from his villa on the outskirts of Tokyo, where he has a clandestine radio transmitter operated by Max Klausen, a wealthy businessman. This ring of spies provides valuable intelligence. On October 15, 1941, a coded message from Doctor Sorge announced to Moscow that Japan would not attack the USSR.

第二天，贝利亚政委向斯大林大元帅和整个国家国防委员会宣布，日本不会对苏联开战。

The next day, Commissar Beria was able to announce to Generalissimo Stalin and the entire State Committee for Defense that Japan would not go to war against the USSR.

理查德·佐尔格则在大崎教授的帮助下维护日本军事当局的进攻美国的想法。与贝利亚保持常年联系的佐尔格博士主张这项让美国卷入战争的政策。最终，佐尔格试图向贝利亚传达期待已久的信息：托拉行动！托拉！托拉！“ 老虎 ！老虎 ！老虎 ！即日本偷袭珍珠港迫在眉睫。大概是12月6日。然而与此同时，佐尔格被日本人逮捕。

Richard Sorge for his part maintains the Japanese military authorities, with the help of Professor Osaki, with the idea of ​​attacking the United States. Doctor Sorge, who maintains permanent contact with Beria, advocates this policy to involve the United States in the war. Eventually, Sorge tries to deliver Beria the long-awaited message that Operation Tora! Torah! Torah! " Tiger ! Tiger ! Tiger ! i.e. the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbour, is imminent. It will probably be for December 6th. In the meantime, however, Sorge is arrested by the Japanese.

1941年12月7日，日本轰炸珍珠港并袭击英属马来亚。美国和英国对日本宣战。12月11日，希特勒对美国宣战。

On December 7, 1941, the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor and raided British Malaya. The United States and Great Britain declare war on Japan. On December 11, Hitler declares war on the United States.

斯大林的顾问之一拉夫连季·贝利亚（Lavrenty Beria）全身心投入到具有国际意义的新事业中。美国作为新的战争伙伴，必须受到更密切的关注，其政策必须根据克里姆林宫的目标进行渗透和影响。1941 年 7 月 12 日后不久，苏联和英国签署了反纳粹友好互助协议，贝利亚建立了一个更大、更有效的间谍网络，可以通过伦敦外交部进行访问。新招募的成员包括哈罗德·阿德里安·拉塞尔（Harold Adrian Russell）、“金”·菲尔比（“Kim” Philby）等英国上流社会成员，以及另外两位优雅且受过良好教育的年轻绅士：唐纳德·麦克莱恩（Donald MacLean）和盖伊·伯吉斯（Guy Burgess）。

Lavrenty Beria, who was among Stalin's advisers, immersed himself in new ventures of international significance. The United States, as a new partner in the war, must be watched more closely and its policy must be penetrated and influenced in accordance with the Kremlin's objectives. When the USSR and Britain signed an agreement of friendship and mutual aid against the Nazis shortly after July 12, 1941, Beria established a larger and more effective spy network, which had access at the Foreign Office in London. Among the recruits were members of English high society like Harold Adrian Russell, "Kim" Philby, and two other refined and educated young gentlemen: Donald MacLean and Guy Burgess.

贝利亚还在美国组织了一个庞大的间谍网络。他深入白宫。甚至在美国参战之前，贝利亚就在他的特工的帮助下与罗斯福总统的一位顾问取得了联系。1940年，阿尔杰·希斯这个人物已经被认定为线人，并受到沃尔特·克里维茨基的谴责。但当时美国并没有类似中央情报局的机构，联邦调查局专门负责监视驻扎在该国的纳粹特使。克里维茨基在华盛顿的揭露被变成了一个笑话。克里维茨基清算后不久，

Beria also organizes a vast spy network in America. He penetrates to the White House. Even before the United States entered the war, Beria managed, thanks to his agents, to get in touch with one of President Roosevelt's advisers. In 1940, this character, Alger Hiss, had already been recognized as an informant and denounced by Walter Krivitski. But at the time, there was no office comparable to the Central Intelligence Agency in the United States, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation dealt exclusively with the surveillance of Nazi emissaries residing there. in the country. The revelation made in Washington by Krivitski was turned into a joke. Shortly after Krivitsky's liquidation,

另一位比克里维茨基更重要的叛逃者就在美国。他是一位前苏联高级人物，1938 年避难到美国。但即使这位叛逃者成为美国当局的线人，他也没有生命危险。他通过特殊手段设法确保了自己的安全。亚历山大·奥尔洛夫 (Alexander Orlov) 是 1938 年内战期间斯大林驻西班牙的全权代表，在得知自己遭到叶约夫的清洗后逃往西方。奥尔洛夫政委设法逃脱了酷刑，并途径法国和加拿大，向华盛顿寻求政治庇护。贝利亚会比任何其他人更乐意杀死这个人，因为他个人讨厌奥尔洛夫。他首先是一个合作者格别乌，时任内务人民委员部外高加索司令，负责守卫波斯和土耳其边境的部队。奥尔洛夫是高加索地区的重要人物，他阻碍了贝利亚的职业生涯。但当奥尔洛夫叛逃时，拉夫连季却无法采取行动。尽管托洛茨基的暗杀表明他可以毫不费力地清除来自任何一个半球的叛逃者，但在奥尔洛夫的案件中，他无法展示他的技巧。这是他的上司、伟大的同志斯大林的特别命令，阻止了贝利亚到达奥尔洛夫。

Another defector, even more important than Krivitski, is in the United States. He is a former high Soviet personality who took refuge in the United States in 1938. But his life is not in danger, even if this defector becomes an informant for the American authorities. He managed to ensure his safety by an exceptional means. Alexander Orlov, who was Stalin's plenipotentiary representative in Spain during the Civil War in 1938, fled to the West after learning he was being purged by Yejov. Commissar Orlov managed to escape his torturers and, passing through France and Canada, he asked for political asylum in Washington. Beria would kill this man with much more pleasure than any other individual, because he personally hates Orlov. He was first a collaborator of theGPU , then commander of the NKVD in Transcaucasia, in charge of the troops guarding the Persian and Turkish borders. An important personality in the Caucasus, Orlov was hampering Beria's career. But when Orlov defected, Lavrenti could not act. Although Trotsky's assassination showed that he had no difficulty liquidating a defector anywhere from either hemisphere, in Orlov's case he could not show his skills. It was a special order from his boss, great comrade Stalin, which prevented Beria from reaching Orlov.

抵达美国后，认识斯大林的奥尔洛夫决定勒索他。在写给克里姆林宫的一封信中，他宣布，他已向律师交存了可能在全世界眼中抹黑斯大林的文件。奥尔洛夫警告他的前上司，如果他被 SMERCH 追随者暗杀，这些论文将立即发表。奥尔洛夫作为内务人民委员部官员积累了丰富的经验，他非常了解独裁者。该策略非常有效。斯大林留下了他一个人。

After landing in America, Orlov, who knew Stalin personally, decided to blackmail him. In a letter sent to the Kremlin, he announced that he had deposited with his lawyer documents which could discredit Stalin in the eyes of the whole world. Orlov warned his former superior that, in case he was assassinated by the SMERCH henchmen, the papers would be published immediately. Orlov had gained a lot of experience as an NKVD official and he knew the dictator very well. The strategy worked perfectly. Stalin left him alone.

在美国建立一个庞大、强大、有效的间谍圈子需要贝利亚付出艰辛的工作和周密的计划，精心策划到最小的细节。识别一个适合接受特殊训练的人需要大量的精力、狡猾和技巧。它还需要很多钱。贝利亚知道，这项工作必须非常谨慎地进行，以确保不发生任何错误，无论多么小，否则可能会引起国际丑闻或产生令人不快的影响，以致破坏美国、英国和美国之间的关系。苏联。第一个目标是拦截来自美国和英国驻莫斯科大使馆的电话和其他个人对话。苏联特工被派驻在那里，负责控制破译密码的钥匙并调查使馆人员的私生活。因此，内务人民委员部的少校和上校被安排担任看门人、司机或厨师，以及仆人、导师和保姆。所有人员每周报告一次他们的观察结果。他们必须报告雇主家中发生的一切，包括他们收到的信件的内容。所有人员每周报告一次他们的观察结果。他们必须报告雇主家中发生的一切，包括他们收到的信件的内容。所有人员每周报告一次他们的观察结果。他们必须报告雇主家中发生的一切，包括他们收到的信件的内容。

The establishment in the United States of a large, powerful and effective circle of spies requires from Beria exhausting work and a meticulous plan, carefully planned down to the smallest detail. It takes a lot of energy, cunning and skill to recognize a man who is suitable for special training. It also requires a lot of money. Beria knows that this work must be carried out with sufficient care to ensure that no mistakes, however small, occur which could cause an international scandal or which would have unpleasant repercussions to the point of ruining relations between the United States, the Great Britain and the Soviet Union. The first objective is to intercept telephone calls and other personal conversations from the American and British embassies in Moscow. Soviet agents were to be placed there to control the keys for deciphering the codes and to investigate the private lives of embassy personnel. Majors and colonels of the NKVD are therefore placed as janitors, drivers or cooks, as well as servants, preceptors and nannies. All report once a week on their observations. They must report on everything that happens in the homes of their employers, including the content of the letters they receive. All report once a week on their observations. They must report on everything that happens in the homes of their employers, including the content of the letters they receive. All report once a week on their observations. They must report on everything that happens in the homes of their employers, including the content of the letters they receive.

贝利亚在距莫斯科约六十公里的贝科沃设立了一所特殊的间谍学院。最有才华的秘密警察、莫斯科大学最优秀的学生、舞台和银幕上最优秀的演员都被召集到贝科沃居住并在那里接受教育。该课程计划是贝利亚的作品。除了体育、地图阅读、无线电技术、破译和破坏之外，它还包括两门强化英语课程，一门是英国口音，另一门是美国口音。我们还讨论英国和美国的习惯、生活方式甚至幽默感等话题。学生们将了解各种形式的颠覆，并学会发现可能有用的人的弱点：他们的赌博、酗酒倾向、对女孩或同性恋的喜爱。他们还研究吸引和引诱美国政府雇用的女性的艺术，然后利用她们作为间谍。他们仍在学习如何与其他特工取得联系以及如何向苏联传递信息。这些人持有假名字的假护照，然后被英国和加拿大送往英国和美国。贝利亚通过两种方式解决了这些活动所需的大量资金的问题。让斯大林相信密集的宣传对于苏联来说是必不可少的，而且代价高昂，贝利亚获得了巨额预算。此外，作为内务人民委员会主席，他还拥有瓦利乌塔·比奥罗特别交流办公室，不久前由GPU组织。valiouta biouro的作用是收集尽可能多的硬通货。贝利亚在该机构使用的官员从事一种“美元调查”，也就是说，他们勒索苏联公民持有的美元。手段包括监禁、酷刑和勒索，以及将涉嫌拥有美国资金的人的家人送往劳改营。该办公室还经营着一个伪造百元大钞的作坊。斯大林几年前批准了这一程序。

Beria installs in Bykovo, about sixty kilometers from Moscow, a special academy for spies. The most gifted officers of the secret police, as well as the most brilliant students of the University of Moscow, the best actors of the stage and the screen are called to reside in Bykovo to receive their education there. The course program is the work of Beria. Besides physical culture, map reading, radio technique, deciphering and sabotage, it includes an intensive English course in two classes, one with a British accent, the other with an American accent. We also deal with topics such as British and American habits, lifestyle or even sense of humor. The students are introduced to all forms of subversion and learn to discover the weak point of people who could be useful: their tendency to gamble, drink, their fondness for girls or for homosexuality. They also study the art of attracting and seducing women employed by the American government, to then use them as spies. They are still learning how to get in touch with other agents and how to pass information to the USSR. These men, provided with false passports under false names, are then sent to Great Britain and the United States by England and by Canada. Beria solves the problem of the large amount of money needed for these activities in two ways. Having convinced Stalin that intensive propaganda was indispensable to the USSR and that it was expensive, Beria got a huge budget. In addition, he has, as head of the NKVD, avaliouta biouro special exchange office, organized shortly before by the GPU . The role of the valiouta biouro is to collect as much hard currency as possible. The officials employed by Beria in this agency engage in a sort of "dollar inquisition," that is, they extort dollars held by Soviet citizens. The means range from imprisonment, torture and blackmail to sending family members of the person suspected of possessing US money to a labor camp. The office also operates a workshop where hundred-dollar bills are counterfeited. Stalin approved this procedure several years ago.

苏联在海外的巧妙宣传很快就取得了成果。贝利亚的手下设法渗透到英国和美国最封闭的圈子里。苏联的生活方式在英国牛津大学和剑桥大学或美国耶鲁大学和哈佛大学的教授和尖子生中变得流行。他们中的许多人渴望体验美好、令人兴奋的共产主义新世界。文学界、艺术界也存在同样的风气。富有的知识分子乐于展示他们的共产主义思想，学者、作家、诗人、记者、电影和戏剧导演也是如此。苏联的一切都很棒。凡是不接受这种观点的人都被称为反动分子，

The subtle enterprise of Soviet propaganda abroad quickly bore fruit. Beria's men manage to infiltrate the most closed circles of Great Britain and the United States. The Soviet lifestyle became fashionable among professors and top students at Oxford and Cambridge in England or Yale and Harvard in the United States. Many of them are eager to experience the wonderful, exciting new communist world. The same atmosphere prevails in literary and artistic circles; rich intellectuals take pleasure in displaying their communist ideas, as do scholars, writers, poets, journalists and film and theater directors. Everything from the USSR is wonderful. Anyone who refuses to adopt this point of view is called a reactionary,

希特勒的前伟大盟友和支持者斯大林大元帅成为“国家的太阳”和“勇敢的乔叔叔”。这一成功很大程度上归功于其内政专员和国家安全负责人。

Generalissimo Stalin, former great ally and supporter of Hitler, becomes the "sun of nations" and the "brave Uncle Joe". This success is largely due to its Commissioner for Home Affairs and Head of State Security.

贝利亚毫不怀疑，只要他掌握了国际间谍活动的所有线索和苏联在西方的所有宣传手段，他对于他的老板来说就是不可替代的。这个人不会解雇他，也不会像对待布哈林和季诺维也夫那样处决他。他们不会像叶努启则那样逮捕他并在监狱的地窖里清算他，他们不会像基洛夫一样暗杀他，他们不会像奥尔忠尼启则那样“自杀”他，他们不会像叶若夫一样解除他的职务。贝利亚充满信心，因为他不会犯这些人所犯的任何错误。他很明智，不会因为留在他的主人的阴影下而感到生气，他的主人在很大程度上感谢拉夫伦蒂，已经成为英国首相温斯顿·丘吉尔爵士和富兰克林·德拉诺·罗斯福总统的亲密朋友，

Beria has no doubt that as long as he holds in his hands all the threads of international espionage and all the means of Soviet propaganda in the West, he is irreplaceable for his boss. This one will not dismiss him, nor will he execute him as he did Bukharin and Zinoviev. They won't arrest him to liquidate him in the cellars of a prison, like Yenukidze, they won't assassinate him like Kirov, they won't "suicide" him like Ordzhonikidze and they won't relieve him of his post like Yezhov. Beria has full confidence because he does not make any of the mistakes made by these men. He is wise enough not to take offense at remaining in the shadow of his master who, largely thanks to Lavrenti, has become a dear friend to British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill and President Franklin Delano Roosevelt,

对于如今担任国防委员会副主席的贝利亚来说，世界闻名的斯大林二号人物对他来说意义不大。拉夫伦蒂的野心是一有机会就穿上领袖的靴子。为此，它以工程师建筑师的精确度进行自我组织。就目前而言，拉夫连季·巴甫洛维奇·贝利亚是他自己军队的主人，几乎是一支私人军队，有五十万强大的、训练有素的官兵和军官，吃得好，穿得好，工资高，并配备了各种现代武器。这些人知道他们的领袖对他们照顾最好，所以他们真诚地支持和服务他。但他们同时也意识到全体人民对他们的仇恨。这加强了他们的团结并促使他们团结在他们的保护者身后。另一方面，贝利亚知道激励他的部队的感觉。他知道他比斯大林对红军更能依赖他们。

Being known worldwide as Stalin's second in command means little to Beria, who is now deputy chairman of the State Defense Committee. Lavrenti's ambition is to put on his leader's boots at the first opportunity. It organizes itself for this purpose with the precision of an engineer-architect. As for the present, Lavrentiy Pavlovich Beria is master of his own army, almost a private army, one and a half million strong and highly trained, well fed, well dressed, well paid and equipped with all varieties of modern weapons. These men know that their leader takes the best care of them, so they sincerely support and serve him. But they are aware at the same time of the hatred that the whole population has for them. This strengthens their unity and pushes them to unite behind their protector. On the other hand, Beria knows the feeling that animates his troops. He knows he can rely on them even more than Stalin on the Red Army.

那么，贝利亚为什么不让约瑟夫·斯大林成为西方世界眼中的“好乔叔叔”呢？西方世界对苏联的一切，从鱼子酱、伏特加、男士阿斯特拉罕帽，到头巾取代了女士帽子，伦敦、巴黎和纽约优雅女性所穿的俄罗斯高筒靴，以及突然变得非常流行的俄罗斯歌曲。

So why wouldn't Beria let Joseph Stalin become "good Uncle Joe" in the eyes of the Western world, which has become so excited about everything from the Soviet Union, from caviar, vodka and astrakhan caps for men? , to the babushka scarves that replaced ladies' hats, to the high Russian boots worn by the elegant women of London, Paris and New York, and to the Russian songs which suddenly became very popular.

我们知道，面对贝利亚专员的这些伟大成就，诸如时不时地绑架女学生、在他办公室的沙发上享受半小时的小事都只是小事。斯大林，“民族的太阳”，懒得去阻止，甚至斥责他的弟子。每个人都有自己的爱好，一个为了拯救苏联及其领导人伟大的斯大林同志而如此努力、如此高效地工作的人，有权稍微放松一下，对吧？

We understand that, in the face of these great achievements of Commissioner Beria, trifles such as the kidnapping of schoolgirls, from time to time, for half an hour of pleasure on a couch in his office, are only trifles. Stalin, the "sun of nations", does not bother to prevent it or even to rebuke his disciple. Everyone has their hobbies and a person who works so hard and so efficiently for the salvation of the USSR and its leader, great comrade Stalin, has a right to a little relaxation, right?

评级

Ratings

41 . 瓦迪斯瓦夫·安德斯中将，《流亡军队》。《波兰第二军团的故事》，伦敦，1949 年。

42 . 作者在沃尔库塔难民营遇见了这些德国定居者。

42 . The author met these German settlers in the Vorkuta camp.

43 . 作者能够看到这些囚犯在露天平台上被运往西伯利亚，而他本人则从遥远北方的劳改营获释并加入了波兰军队的总部，摆脱了布祖卢克的安德斯将军的束缚。

43 . The author was able to see these prisoners transported to Siberia on open platforms as he himself was released from a labor camp in the far north and joined the headquarters of the Polish army. Free of General Anders in Bouzoulouk.

第39章

Chapter 39

世界上最伟大的表演

The greatest show in the world

1943年春，西方列强与苏联之间爆发了一场国际丑闻。在仍被德国人占领的斯摩棱斯克市附近，托德组织的人员正忙着修复被轰炸严重损坏的铁路和主要道路。托德营被德国人指派到战斗工兵师，负责挖掘战壕、修建桥梁和进行其他工作，由在纳粹占领的国家强制招募的工人组成：罗马尼亚、捷克斯洛伐克、匈牙利、波兰、丹麦、荷兰和法国。

In the spring of 1943 an international scandal broke out between the Western powers and the USSR. Near the city of Smolensk, still occupied by the Germans, the men of the Todt organization are busy repairing the railways and the main roads badly damaged by the bombardments. The Todt battalions, assigned by the Germans to the combat engineer divisions to dig trenches, build bridges and carry out other work, are made up of workers recruited by force in the countries occupied by the Nazis: Romania, Czechoslovakia, Hungary , Poland, Denmark, the Netherlands and France.

1943年4月，在距离斯摩棱斯克不远的地方，托德组织的几名男子在第聂伯河沿岸的卡廷森林里工作时，偶然发现了一个官兵乱葬坑。所有人都穿着既不是俄罗斯也不是德国的制服。纳粹当局被传唤到现场开始调查。这表明这些尸体是苏联入侵波兰后红军俘获的约5000名波兰战俘的尸体。根据贝利亚的说法，失败的波兰人由于对他们犯下的“严重错误”，无法加入在俄罗斯领土上建立的自由波兰军队。

In April 1943, not far from Smolensk, a few men from the Todt organization, working in the Katyn forest on the banks of the Dnieper, discovered by chance a mass grave of officers and soldiers. All wear uniforms that are neither Russian nor German. The Nazi authorities summoned to the scene begin an investigation. This reveals that the corpses are those of approximately 5,000 Polish prisoners of war captured by the Red Army after the invasion of Poland by the USSR. It was the failing Poles who, according to Beria, because of the “serious error” committed against them, could not join the Free Polish Army created on Russian territory.

内务人民委员部部队消灭了他们。

NKVD troops liquidated them.

纳粹为了自己的利益，不惜利用这场屠杀。1943 年 4 月 13 日，柏林广播电台宣布，在斯摩棱斯克地区发现了一座被苏联秘密警察屠杀的大型集体坟墓。

The Nazis do not hesitate to use this massacre for their own interests. On April 13, 1943, Radio Berlin announced that a large mass grave of men massacred by the Soviet secret police had been discovered in the Smolensk sector.

伦敦的波兰流亡政府和英国当局起初认为纳粹的信息只是谎言，是又一个愤世嫉俗的宣传伎俩。然而，德国人表示，他们已准备好证明其真实性，并要求日内瓦国际红十字会任命一个委员会，参与尸体的挖掘工作。红十字会接受了这一提议，但条件是波兰政府、苏联和第三帝国三方都同意进行调查。英国政府和伦敦的波兰政府确信，斯大林会很高兴看到像瑞士红十字会这样客观的机构审查如此重要的国际事件。不到一周前，莫斯科广播电台，由民政事务专员控制，称这一指控是诽谤，并提出了完全不同的事实版本。这实际上是纳粹挑衅苏联所犯下的罪行。不过，克里姆林宫没有对日内瓦的信函做出回应。作为回应，斯大林向波兰驻伦敦代表发出简明扼要的照会，宣布苏联决定与波兰自由政府断绝外交关系。

The Polish government-in-exile in London and the British authorities at first assume that the Nazi information is just a lie, another cynical propaganda trick. However, the Germans say they are ready to demonstrate its veracity and ask the International Red Cross in Geneva to appoint a commission which would take part in the exhumation of the bodies. The Red Cross accepts the proposal, but on the condition that the three parties involved the Polish government, the USSR and the Third Reich all consent to the investigation being carried out. The British administration and the Polish government in London are certain that Stalin will be happy that an international event of this importance is examined by an institution as objective as the Swiss Red Cross. No more than a week earlier, Radio Moscow, controlled by the Home Affairs Commissioner, called the accusation a slander and produced an entirely different version of the facts. It would actually be a crime committed by the Nazis to provoke the Soviet Union. However, the Kremlin does not respond to the letter from Geneva. In response, Stalin sends a pithy note to the Polish representatives in London, announcing that the USSR has decided to break off diplomatic relations with the Free Government of Poland.

希特勒很高兴能够向世界展示斯大林的红色土壤并不比他自己的棕色恐怖更残酷，而且纳粹德国不应该被视为对野蛮行为的垄断。德国人带领一个由医生和多位专家组成的国际委员会进入卡廷森林。这些学者经过仔细检查后得出的结论是，尸体的埋葬时期、杀死他们的子弹以及伤口的形状（这是俄罗斯三角刺刀的某种型号的特征）毫无疑问地证明了这一点。这场大屠杀是苏联特种部队所为。尸检目击者中有几名美国和英国军官：美国陆军中校约翰·H·范·弗利特 (John H. Van Vliet Jr.)、美国陆军上尉唐纳德·B·范·弗利特 (Donald B. Van Vliet Jr.)。斯图尔特和英国陆军上尉斯坦利·B·吉尔德博士以及其他被德国人强行带走的囚犯。他们首先坚信这次处决是纳粹组织的，他们正确地认为纳粹是敌人，而且他们的盟友苏联不可能犯下如此令人发指的暴行，最后他们说服自己，罪行是斯大林犯下的，他的国家安全委员拉夫连季·贝利亚。

Hitler rejoiced in being able to show the world that Stalin's red soil was no less brutal than his own brown terror and that Nazi Germany should not be seen as having a monopoly on barbarism. The Germans led an international committee of doctors and various experts into the Katyn forest. These scholars, after careful examination, come to the conclusion that the period of burial of the bodies, the bullets that killed them and the shape of their wounds, which is characteristic of a certain model of the Russian triangular bayonet, prove without the slightest doubt that this massacre was the work of Soviet special troops. Among the autopsy witnesses are several American and British officers: US Army Lieutenant Colonel John H. Van Vliet Jr., US Army Captain Donald B. Stewart and, of the British Army, Captain Dr. Stanley B. Gilder and others who, prisoners of the Germans, were brought by force. At first firmly convinced that the execution had been organized by the Nazis, whom they rightly considered to be the enemy, and that their ally the USSR could not have committed such an abominable atrocity, they ended up persuading themselves that the crime was committed by Stalin and his Commissar of State Security, Lavrenty Beria.

几个月后，1943 年 9 月，苏联军队重新夺回斯摩棱斯克和卡廷森林，克里姆林宫试图平息丑闻并挽回面子。贝利亚让莫斯科广播电台宣布成立一个“特别委员会，以确定在卡廷森林中被德国法西斯入侵者俘虏的波兰军官的处决情况”。

A few months later, when in September 1943 the Soviet army retook Smolensk and the Katyn Forest, the Kremlin tried to quell the scandal and save face. Beria had Radio Moscow announce the creation of a "Special Commission to determine the circumstances of the execution of Polish officers taken prisoner by the German-Fascist invaders in the Katyn forest".

这个完全由苏联人、共产党员和红军高级军官组成的新委员会甚至在开始调查之前就从苏联广播电台和苏联媒体获悉，卡廷森林大屠杀是由苏联人实施的。德国人。换句话说，命令委员会只能确认国家安全局局长颁布的法令。

This new commission, composed entirely of Soviets, members of the Communist Party and senior officers of the Red Army, was informed by Soviet radio and the Soviet press, even before it had begun its investigation, that the massacre of the Katyn forest was committed by the Germans. In other words, the orders commission can only confirm what has been decreed by the head of State Security.

在特别委员会前往大屠杀现场之前，贝利亚派遣了一批最有能力的军官前往斯摩棱斯克，其任务是组织这场大屠杀。首先，内务人民委员部的一个排聚集了居住在邻近村庄的所有农民，无论男女。那些看起来足够聪明、可以被利用的人被告知，一个委员会即将到来，村民们必须自愿履行该委员会的职责，作为德国人将囚犯带入森林枪决那天的意外目击者。秘密警察逐字逐句地教他们的俘虏说什么，并命令他们记住。

Before the special commission goes to the scene of the massacre, Beria sends a group of his most able officers to Smolensk whose task is to organize the spectacle. To begin with, a platoon of NKVD forces gathers all the peasants, men and women, who live in the neighboring villages. Those who seem smart enough to be used are told that a commission is coming soon and the villagers must serve it voluntarily, as accidental witnesses to the day the Germans brought the prisoners into the forest to be shot. The secret police officers teach their captives word by word what to say and order them to memorize it.

随后，由政治局委员尼古拉·切尔韦尔尼克（Nikolaï Chvernik）担任主席的委员会离开莫斯科前往斯摩棱斯克。在卡廷森林待了几天后，委员会主要致力于询问村民，然后返回莫斯科。法医专家立即起草调查报告，并经贝利亚核实和批准后，将调查结果公布于众。

Then, the commission chaired by Nikolaï Chvernik, member of the Politburo, leaves Moscow for Smolensk. After a few days spent in the Katyn forest, where it mainly devotes itself to questioning the villagers, the commission returns to Moscow. The report of the investigation carried out by the forensic experts is immediately drawn up and, after verification and approval by Beria, the findings are made public.

贝利亚的下一步是邀请驻莫斯科的外国记者观看一场精心准备的表演。那里有11名美国记者：合众社社长兼NBC记者亨利·克拉伦斯·卡西迪、《纽约时报》的威廉·H·劳伦斯、哥伦比亚广播公司的詹姆斯·弗莱明、UP的亨利·夏皮罗、《伦敦时报》和《纽约时报》的拉尔夫·帕克，让·尚佩努瓦、哈罗德·金、爱德华·安格利、H·劳特巴赫、亚历山大·沃斯和爱德华·史蒂文斯。

Beria's next step was to invite foreign correspondents accredited in Moscow to a well-prepared performance. There are eleven American reporters there: United Press bureau chief and NBC correspondent Henry Clarence Cassidy, William H. Lawrence of the New York Times , James Fleming of CBS, Henry Shapiro for UP, Ralph Parker of London Times and New York Times , Jean Champernois, Harold King, Edward Angly, H. Lauterbach, Alexander Worth and Edward Stevens.

美国大使威廉·艾夫里尔·哈里曼邀请他的女儿凯瑟琳加入记者团，并任命美国驻莫斯科大使馆三等秘书约翰·F·梅尔比参加卡廷之行。1944 年 1 月 25 日，大使在一份严格保密的电报中向富兰克林·D·罗斯福总统和国务卿通报了这次访问。他透露，“在场的任何人都无法科学地判断在他们面前进行的尸检结果。此外，除了对少数可用证人进行正式询问外，他们不被允许进行独立调查。记者记录了他们所见所闻的证词，但没有发表意见，45 … »

The United States Ambassador, William Averell Harriman, asks his daughter Kathleen to join the group of journalists and he appoints John F. Melby, Third Secretary of the American Embassy in Moscow, to participate in the trip to Katyn. The ambassador informed President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the Secretary of State of this visit in a strictly confidential telegram dated January 25, 1944. He revealed that "no one in attendance was able to scientifically judge the results of the autopsies performed in their presence. Moreover, they were not allowed to carry out independent investigations, apart from the official questioning of the few available witnesses. Correspondents recorded depositions relating what they had seen without expressing opinions,45 … »

斯摩棱斯克之行结束后，凯瑟琳·哈里曼小姐尽管既不是记者，也不是专家，无法认出贝利亚的诡计和狡猾，但她还是写了一份详细的报告，其中写道：

After her trip to Smolensk, Miss Kathleen Harriman, despite being neither a journalist nor an expert able to recognize Beria's trickery and cunning, writes a detailed report in which she writes:

1944 年 1 月 23 日，外国媒体成员被带到斯摩棱斯克，直接审查卡廷事件委员会收集的证据。

On January 23, 1944, members of the foreign press were taken to Smolensk to directly examine the evidence gathered by the Katyn Incident Commission.

该小组能够看到卡廷森林的墓葬和尸体的尸检证词。由于没有一个成员能够评估所提供的科学证据，因此必须按其表面价值接受。

The group was able to see the Katyn Forest burials and the post-mortem testimonies of the bodies. Since none of the members were in a position to assess the scientific evidence that was provided, it had to be accepted at face value.

委员会和证人提供的证词缺乏细节，而且以美国标准来看是薄弱的。我们应该相信苏联高级官员的说法是真实的，因为他们说这些是真的。

Testimony provided by the commission and by witnesses was scanty in detail and weak by American standards. We were expected to believe the claims of senior Soviet officials to be true, because they said they were true.

并进一步 ：

And further :

证人的配合非常好，他们看起来顺从而不是被吓倒，他们的角色已经被熟记在心。

The witnesses overlapped very well and they seemed submissive rather than intimidated, their role having been learned by heart.

当最后一位证人出庭时，会问一些一般性问题，有些与事件有关，有些则无关。然而很快，外交部新闻司的代表站了起来，说我们最好打断一下，因为我们的火车马上就要出发了。我的明显印象是委员会松了一口气。我们告诉他们为我们表演一场节目。演出结束了，他们不想再被打扰了。会议没有任何进展就结束了。

When the last witness had been heard, general questions were asked, some related to the incident, some not. Quickly, however, the representatives of the press department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs stood up and said that we had better interrupt since our train was to leave soon. I had the distinct impression that the committee was relieved. We told them to put on a show for us. The show was over and they didn't want to be bothered anymore. The meeting ended without further ado .

美国驻莫斯科大使馆三等秘书约翰·梅尔比 (John F. Melby) 的说法更令人怀疑。他宣称：

The account compiled by the Third Secretary of the American Embassy in Moscow, John F. Melby, is even more skeptical. He declares :

晚上，委员会专门召开了一次会议来审问证人……很快就发现，这次会议是为记者准备的，而证人只是在重复委员会已经告诉过他们的故事。这场表演是在弧光灯炽热、刺眼的灯光下和电影摄影机前上演的。总共有五名证人出庭，他们对新闻发布会上的言论没有任何补充。记者询问证人的尝试遭到阻止，最终只能通过委员会成员才勉强允许。证人作完陈述后，被尽快全部带走。

In the evening, the commission devoted a session to the interrogation of witnesses… It quickly became clear that the session had been prepared for the correspondents and that the witnesses were only repeating stories that the commission had already given them. The show was staged under the hot, blinding light of arc lamps and in front of movie cameras. Five witnesses in all were produced who added nothing to what had been said at the press conference. Attempts by correspondents to question witnesses were discouraged and eventually only allowed reluctantly and only through the members of the commission. The witnesses were all removed as soon as possible after they had finished their statements.

记者们纷纷提出具体而又粗暴的问题，会场气氛逐渐紧张。午夜时分，突然宣布我们的火车一小时后出发。

The atmosphere of the session gradually grew tense as the correspondents asked specific and generally brutal questions one after the other. At midnight it was abruptly announced that our train was to leave in an hour.

委员会成员当然对向他们提出的直接问题根本不满意。回程时，陪同我们的外交部官员过度担心……我们是否被说服。显然，从俄罗斯的角度来看，该文件在几个方面都不完整，而且整理得很糟糕，而且这种场面是为了记者的利益而整理的，没有独立调查或核实的可能性。然而，另一方面，尽管有回避，俄罗斯的案例还是令人信服的47。

The members of the commission were certainly not happy at all with the direct questions put to them. On the return trip, the Foreign Affairs officials who accompanied us were overly concerned…whether we were convinced. It is obvious that the file, from the Russian point of view, is incomplete in several respects, that it is badly put together and that the spectacle has been put together for the benefit of the correspondents, without the possibility of independent investigation or verification. On the other hand, however, and despite evasions, the Russian case is convincing 47 .

这种操纵事实来愚弄西方的方式是苏联宣传办公室的特点，该办公室是拉夫连季·巴甫洛维奇·贝利亚领导下的内务人民委员部的机构之一。在这种情况下，尽管情节并非没有错误，但贝利亚因“对苏联做出的杰出贡献”而被上级斯大林大元帅授予社会主义劳动英雄荣誉称号也就不足为奇了。 。

This way of manipulating facts to fool the West is characteristic of the Soviet Propaganda Office, one of the agencies of the People's Commissariat of Internal Affairs under Lavrentiy Pavlovich Beria. Under these conditions, despite the fact that the plot was not free from faults, it is not surprising that Beria was rewarded by his superior, Generalissimo Stalin, with the honorary title of hero of socialist labor. for "extraordinary services rendered to the Soviet Union".

评级

Ratings

第40章

Chapter 40

华盛顿的苏联采购委员会

The Soviet Purchasing Commission in Washington

1941 年希特勒对苏联盟友的意外袭击决定了克里姆林宫政策的彻底改变。现在斯大林和他的四位顾问智囊团必须向西方寻求帮助。然而，这一事件并没有改变人们的普遍态度。征服世界并将其置于共产主义枷锁之下的想法仍然盛行，这种想法以苏联标志锤子和镰刀在蓝色地球仪上的轮廓为代表。

The unexpected attack on its Soviet ally by Hitler in 1941 determined a complete change in Kremlin policy. Now Stalin and his brain trust of four advisers must seek help from the West. However, this event does not alter the general attitude. The idea of ​​conquering the world and placing it under the communist yoke represented by the Soviet emblem of the hammer and sickle silhouetted against a blue terrestrial globe, still prevails.

事实证明，加入德国的敌人西方同盟国的阵营对于苏联来说是必要的。但这并没有把他对西方文化、文明和财富的仇恨和自卑感转变为爱情甚至友谊的突然爆发。

Joining the camp of the Western Allies, the enemies of Germany, proves to be a necessity for the Soviet Union. But that doesn't turn his feelings of hatred and inferiority towards Western culture, civilization and wealth into a sudden outburst of love or even friendship.

苏联急需西方列强的帮助。因此，苏联向美国、英国和法国求助就是为了这个目的。新的互助条约给俄罗斯带来了额外的优势。它们使他们更容易渗透到盟国的国家，使他们更容易获得他们的军事和经济秘密，以及其他重要信息，以便他们以后可以利用这些信息为自己谋取利益，对抗当前的战斗兄弟。

The USSR badly needs the help of the Western powers. Therefore, the Soviet Union turns to the United States, Great Britain and France for this sole purpose. The new Mutual Assistance Pacts give the Russians an added advantage. They make it easier for them to infiltrate the countries of their allies and make it easier for them to obtain their military and economic secrets, as well as other important information that they can later use for their own benefit against their current combat brothers. .

贝利亚政委牢记列宁在 1920 年 4 月 3 日第九次党代表大会上表达的基本格言“一个好的共产党员同时也是一个好的契机”，除了他在比科沃的间谍学院之外，贝利亚还为外交官组织了高度专业化的课程、大使、武官和其他苏联驻外官员。政治、经济、社会、文化和艺术领域新开放的国际关系领域使苏联有机会向国外派遣官员并设立一些委员会。除了精通政治专家、学者、作家和音乐家之外，这些人还必须在贝利亚的指导下通过考试，成为训练有素的间谍。

Remembering the fundamental maxim expressed by Lenin at the Ninth Party Congress on April 3, 1920 "A good Communist is at the same time a good Chekist", Commissar Beria organizes, in addition to his spy academy in Bykovo, a highly specialized course for diplomats, ambassadors, attachés and other Soviet officials abroad. The newly opened sectors of international relations in the political, economic, social, cultural and artistic spheres gave the Soviet Union the opportunity to send officials abroad and to establish a number of commissions. In addition to their proficiency as political pundits, scholars, writers, and musicians, these men must, under Beria's directives, pass exams to become highly trained spies.

其中一个间谍小组早在 1943 年就被派往美国，当时苏联声称自己是美国忠实的战友。它被称为苏联采购委员会，由受过高等教育的人和训练有素的代理人组成。在接受阿纳斯塔斯·米高扬的采访后，贝利亚实现了另一个目标。贝利亚通过同时负责苏联租借法案的对外贸易人民委员米高扬，指示采购委员会负责人、红军将军列昂尼德·鲁登科及其团队，寻找有关该行业的任何秘密信息。尤其是美国的军工行业。该委员会有一千多名员工，全部在贝利亚学院接受过培训，任务是从美国作品中获取尽可能多的秘密。他们接受训练来观察新的军事产品，如炸弹、大炮和坦克、新的工业流程和美国的政治。苏联采购委员会在贝利亚政委的指导下，在严酷的战争气氛下，在“俄罗斯人做了什么！”的基础上在美国运作。他们是我们的盟友，斯大林先生是勇敢的乔叔叔和我们真诚的朋友”。在严酷的战争气氛下，基于“无论俄罗斯人做什么！他们是我们的盟友，斯大林先生是勇敢的乔叔叔和我们真诚的朋友”。在严酷的战争气氛下，基于“无论俄罗斯人做什么！他们是我们的盟友，斯大林先生是勇敢的乔叔叔和我们真诚的朋友”。

One of these spy cells was sent to the United States as early as 1943, when the Soviet Union claimed to be a faithful comrade in arms of America. It is called the Soviet Purchasing Commission and is made up of highly educated men and highly trained agents. After an interview with Anastase Mikoyan, Beria achieves yet another goal. Through Mikoyan, the People's Commissar for Foreign Trade who is also in charge of Lend-Lease for the Soviet Union, Beria instructs the head of the purchasing commission, Red Army General Leonid Rudenko, and his team , to seek any secret information on the industry, particularly the military industry of the United States. The commission has more than a thousand employees, all trained in the Beria academy, tasked with obtaining as many secrets from American productions as possible. They are trained to observe new military productions such as bombs, artillery and tanks, new industrial processes and the politics of the United States. The Soviet Purchasing Commission operates in America under the direction of Commissar Beria, in a harsh atmosphere of war and on the basis of “What do the Russians do! They are our allies and Mr. Stalin is a brave Uncle Joe and our sincere friend”. in a harsh atmosphere of war and on the basis of “Whatever the Russians do! They are our allies and Mr. Stalin is a brave Uncle Joe and our sincere friend”. in a harsh atmosphere of war and on the basis of “Whatever the Russians do! They are our allies and Mr. Stalin is a brave Uncle Joe and our sincere friend”.

内政委员主要感兴趣的是克里姆林宫所谓的“超级租借”，即美国的秘密。这些被盗信息通过空运和海运到达贝利亚。这些信息装在手提箱中运送，不受外交豁免权的搜查，其中包含照片、地图、影印机、图表以及设备和机械的详细描述。美国人。1943年苏联采购委员会抵达华盛顿仅几个月后，该委员会的成员就获得了最秘密的信息，并将其发送到拉夫连季·巴甫洛维奇·贝利亚的警察局。这些信息涉及原子弹的基本元素铀。她在前往苏联的途中经过蒙大拿州的大瀑布空军基地。

The Commissar for Internal Affairs is mainly interested in what the Kremlin calls “super-lend-lease”, that is to say in American secrets. This stolen information reaches Beria by air and by sea. It is shipped in suitcases protected from search by diplomatic immunity and contains photographs, maps, photostats, charts and detailed descriptions of devices and machinery. Americans. Only a few months after the arrival in Washington in 1943 of the Soviet Purchasing Commission, the members of this commission obtained the most secret information and sent it to the police station of Lavrenti Pavlovich Beria. The information concerns uranium, an essential element of the atomic bomb. She passes through Great Falls Air Force Base in Montana on her way to the Soviet Union.

1944 年 4 月 4 日，成千上万的美国人读到了《纽约时报》头版上标题为“苏联公务员辞职”的耸人听闻的新闻。该报透露，华盛顿的苏联采购委员会官员维克托·克拉夫琴科(Victor Kravchenko)已向美国申请政治庇护，他指责苏联政府奉行双边外交政策，尽管它明显希望与美国合作，与英格兰。”超过俄罗斯人民”。

On April 4, 1944, thousands of Americans read sensational news under the headline “Soviet Civil Servant Resigns,” printed on the front page of The New York Times.The newspaper reveals that an official of the Soviet Purchasing Commission in Washington, Victor Kravchenko, who has requested political asylum in the United States, accuses the Soviet government of pursuing a two-sided foreign policy despite its apparent desire for collaboration with the United States and with England. He also denounces the Soviet administration for not granting political and civic freedoms to the Russian people who are "subjected...to untold oppression and cruelties while the NKVD, the Soviet secret police, acting through its thousands of spies, continues to maintain unbridled domination over the people of Russia".

在维克托·安德烈耶维奇·克拉夫琴科宣布叛逃的当天，内政专员兼国家安全负责人索要了他的个人档案。贝利亚检查了这些文件，并决定让逃亡者遭受与沃尔特·克里维茨基相同的命运。

The very day when the defection of Victor Andreyevich Kravtchenko was announced, his personal file was requested by the Commissioner for Internal Affairs and Head of State Security. Beria examines the papers and decides to reserve the fugitive the same fate as Walter Krivitski.

然而，这个新案件的执行难度要大得多。克拉夫琴科在飞往纽约的当天就召开了新闻发布会，宣布自己受到美国舆论的保护。他成为了一位杰出人物。尽管受到美国侦探的保护，克拉夫琴科在接下来的一年里大部分时间都躲在一位老太太的公寓里。诺曼·哈普古德，美国外交官的遗孀。这位俄罗斯难民在家中躲避贝利亚的特工，他声称这些特工受命暗杀他，作为对揭露苏联在美国和世界各地间谍活动的惩罚。

This new case, however, is much more difficult to carry out. The very day of his flight to New York, Kravchenko called a press conference and declared that he placed himself under the protection of American public opinion. He became a prominent figure. Although protected by American detectives, Kravchenko hid for most of the following year in the apartment of an elderly lady, Mrs. Norman Hapgood, widow of an American diplomat. The Russian refugee finds shelter in her home from Beria's agents who he claims were ordered to assassinate him as punishment for exposing Soviet espionage activities in America and around the world world.

克拉夫琴科在他的回忆录中写道：哈普古德（Hapgood），通晓多种语言，被翻译成英语。两年后，即 1946 年，他的自传出版了。这本书的标题“我选择了自由”成为任何决心离开共产主义国家前往西方的人的流行表达。

Kravchenko writes his memoirs that Mrs. Hapgood, a polyglot, translated into English. Two years later, in 1946, his autobiography came out of the press. The title of the book, I chose freedom , becomes a popular expression for anyone who has resolved to leave a communist country for the West.

作者讲述了他在逃亡当晚的一些想法，当他决定从苏联驻华盛顿大使馆逃往纽约时，他看到了贝利亚追随者的复仇欲望散布到世界各地所带来的巨大危险。 。

The author tells the story of the thoughts that agitated him the night of his flight, when, having decided to escape from the Soviet Embassy in Washington to New York, he saw the enormous danger that the desire for revenge from Beria's henchmen scattered across the world.

当克拉夫琴科写道，苏联政权“将对我宣判死刑”时，他意识到了自己这一步骤的后果。他的特工总是会困扰我的生活。他们会跟踪我并在我的窗户下站岗，如果他们的主人命令他们，他们就会射杀我。

Kravchenko is aware of the consequences of his step when he writes that the regime of the USSR “will pronounce a death sentence against me. Always, his secret agents will haunt my life. They will track me and stand guard under my windows, and if their masters order them, they will shoot me.

这本书立即成为畅销书。维克多·克拉夫琴科（Victor Kravtchenko）很快在两大洲变得非常出名，任何人都无法立即清算他。他的突然死亡非常可疑，可能会引起国际丑闻。判决的执行必须推迟。拉夫连季·贝利亚有时间。他很有耐心，不介意等待。

The book immediately became a bestseller. Victor Kravtchenko is quickly becoming far too famous on both continents for anyone to liquidate him right away. His sudden death would be very suspicious and could cause an international scandal. The execution of the sentence must be delayed. Lavrenty Beria has time. He is patient and does not mind waiting.

克拉夫琴科获得的版税使他能够住在纽约市最高档社区之一、靠近中央公园的舒适公寓里。多年过去了，自杀的死刑判决却没有被推翻。

The royalties that Kravchenko receives allow him to live in a comfortable apartment in one of the most upscale neighborhoods of New York City, near Central Park. Years pass, but the suicide death sentence is not overturned.

维克多·克拉夫琴科随后将出席全国非美活动委员会，并提供有关苏联间谍特工（包括高级外交官）窃取“大量”美国机密的证据。克拉夫琴科承认，他本人曾经不得不帮忙把从俄罗斯窃取的信息装进手提箱，这些信息是在外交豁免权的掩护下发送的。他还认识到苏联外交和间谍活动是密不可分的。“每一位苏联外交官，克拉夫琴科都会肯定，无论是俄罗斯驻联合国代表雅科夫·马利克，还是苏联驻华盛顿大使亚历山大·帕纽什金，或者他们在巴黎或伦敦的同事，都为此类活动做了充分的准备，并拥有丰富的经验48 . »

Victor Kravchenko will later appear before the National Un-American Activities Committee and give evidence about Soviet espionage agents, including top diplomats, who stole "tons" of American secrets. Kravchenko will confess that he himself once had to help stuff suitcases with information stolen from Russia and sent under cover of diplomatic immunity. He also recognizes that Soviet diplomacy and espionage are inseparable. "Every Soviet diplomat, Kravchenko will affirm, whether Yakov Malik, Russian delegate to the United Nations, or Alexander Paniushkin, Soviet ambassador in Washington, or their colleagues in Paris or London, received intensive preparation for this kind of activity and has extensive experience48 . »

非美活动委员会的一名成员、宾夕法尼亚州民主党众议员弗朗西斯·E·沃尔特想知道苏联驻美国外交人员是否从事间谍活动，克拉夫琴科回答说：“当然。” 它是49系统的一部分。»

Asked by one of the members of the Un-American Activities Committee, Deputy Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who wants to know if the agents of Soviet diplomacy stationed in the United States deal with espionage, Kravtchenko replied: " Absolutely. It's part of the 49 system . »

维克多·克拉夫琴科最终将经历他在回忆录中宣布的命运。1966 年 2 月 25 日，一个悲伤的早晨，他被发现死在纽约的公寓里。他的死亡和确定自杀的线索让人想起克里维茨基涉嫌自杀的情况。克里维茨基去世的同一个月，也就是二月，克拉夫琴科留下了一张纸条，就像克里维茨基一样，他说他决定用自己的手枪向右侧太阳穴开枪来结束自己的生命。

Victor Kravtchenko will end up experiencing the fate he announced in his memoirs. On a sad morning, February 25, 1966, he was found dead in his New York apartment. His death and the clues establishing suicide recall the circumstances surrounding Krivitski's alleged suicide. The same month that Krivitsky died, February, Kravchenko leaves a note, exactly like Krivitsky, stating that he has decided to end his life by shooting himself in the right temple with his own pistol.

不同的是，克里维茨基的左轮手枪靠近身体，而克拉夫琴科的左轮手枪则放在运动夹克的口袋里。官方承认克拉夫琴科的死因是自杀。但这是一次奇怪的自杀：绝望的男子在右侧太阳穴开枪自杀后，会小心翼翼地将武器放回夹克口袋里。

The difference is that Krivitsky's revolver was lying close to the body, while Kravchenko's will be in the pocket of his sports jacket. The officially recognized cause of Kravchenko's death is suicide. But it is a strange suicide: the desperate man, after having shot himself in the right temple, would have carefully replaced the weapon in his jacket pocket.

从选择自由的那一刻起，直到二十二年后他去世，克拉夫琴科一直生活在恐惧之中。邻居们形容他“对每个人，尤其是陌生人，总是感到震惊和怀疑，非常害怕，非常神秘，似乎在回头看，好像感觉到有人在跟踪他。50。莫斯科坚持不懈的内政委员拉夫连季·贝利亚下令多次尝试刺杀这名俄罗斯叛逃者。克拉夫琴科声称，仅 1949 年一年，共产党特工就进行了四次此类尝试。警察闯入他的家，在加利福尼亚州三次，在纽约两次，却发现他不在家。几年后，他击退了两名强行闯入他纽约公寓的入侵者。克拉夫琴科拿到了他持有许可证的左轮手枪，打伤了其中一名袭击者，而另一名袭击者则逃跑了。

From the moment he chose freedom until his death twenty-two years later, Kravchenko lived in constant fear. Neighbors described him as "perpetually appalled and suspicious of everyone, especially strangers, very fearful, very secretive and seeming to be looking over his shoulder as if he sensed someone was following him. 50. Moscow's persevering Commissar of Internal Affairs, Lavrenty Beria, ordered several attempts on the life of the Russian defector. Kravchenko claimed that in 1949 alone four such attempts were made by Communist agents. Officers broke into his home, three times in California and twice in New York, only to find that he was out. A few years later, he fended off two intruders who had forced their way into his New York apartment. Kravchenko was able to reach his revolver, for which he had a permit, and wounded one of the assailants while the other fled.

维克多·克拉夫琴科在贝利亚幸存了近十三年，但国家安全总政委对他宣判的自杀判决仍然有效。它必须被应用。

Victor Kravchenko managed to survive almost thirteen years in Beria, but the suicide sentence that the Commissar General for State Security had pronounced against him was still in force. It had to be applied.

评级

Ratings

48 . 《纽约时报》，1950 年 3 月 8 日。

48 . The New York Times , March 8, 1950.

49 . 同上。

49 . Ibid.

50 . 纽约先驱论坛报，1966 年 2 月 26 日。

50 . New York Herald Tribune , February 26, 1966.

第41章

Chapter 41

苏联、斯拉夫和兄弟军队

The Soviet, Slavic and Fraternal Army

由苏联战俘组成并由安德斯将军指挥的波兰军队并不包括所有俘虏。贝利亚拥有的强迫劳动营中关押的波兰囚犯的确切名单永远不会被透露。1943 年，当波兰军队离开苏联，与蒙哥马利元帅的英国第 8集团军一起参加意大利战役时，贝利亚命令古拉格释放仍在铁丝网后面的波兰人。

The Polish forces made up of prisoners of war in the USSR and placed under the command of General Anders did not include all the captives. The exact list of Polish prisoners held in the forced labor camps, which Beria possesses, will never be revealed. When Polish troops left the Soviet Union to take part in the Italian campaign alongside Marshal Montgomery's British 8th Army in 1943, Beria ordered the GULAG to release the Poles who were still behind the barbed wire.

在伦敦的波兰政府与苏联断绝外交关系后，贝利亚不再有义务召集更多的波兰人军团并将他们移交给国家当局。这些没有祖国的人，既不是苏联公民，也不是外国土地上的自由波兰人，他们受到狱卒的摆布，随时有可能被送回西伯利亚的矿井，或者像他们在卡廷森林的同胞一样被处决，尽管贝利亚并没有这样做。打算重复这个“严重错误”。内政委员制定了一项不同的计划来使用这些囚犯。为此，他任命了齐格蒙德·柏林上校，后者在波兰自由军撤离前夕离开部队加入了红军。这次开小差是柏林在俄罗斯学院接受训练的结果，该学院是专门为波兰叛逃者开设的，位于莫斯科附近的马拉霍夫卡的“欢乐别墅”，也称为“幸福天堂”。贝利亚创建的这个培训中心旨在为红色波兰培养高管人员，现已开始取得成果。根据贝利亚的计划，刚刚解放的波兰人可以选择：要么加入一支在苏联指挥下的波兰共产主义军队，这支军队将在德国战败后夺取波兰，要么与安德斯将军指挥的同胞作战，如果两者之间的情况不同的话与西方列强 贝利亚创建的这个培训中心旨在为红色波兰培养高管人员，现已开始取得成果。根据贝利亚的计划，刚刚解放的波兰人可以选择：要么加入一支在苏联指挥下的波兰共产主义军队，这支军队将在德国战败后夺取波兰，要么与安德斯将军指挥的同胞作战，如果两者之间的情况不同的话与西方列强 贝利亚创建的这个培训中心旨在为红色波兰培养高管人员，现已开始取得成果。根据贝利亚的计划，刚刚解放的波兰人可以选择：要么加入一支在苏联指挥下的波兰共产主义军队，这支军队将在德国战败后夺取波兰，要么与安德斯将军指挥的同胞作战，如果两者之间的情况不同的话与西方列强51，否则，如果这个想法不让他们高兴，他们将不得不返回西伯利亚。

After the severance of diplomatic relations between the Polish government in London and the USSR, Beria was no longer obliged to raise up further regiments of Poles and hand them over to their national authorities. These men without a homeland, neither Soviet citizens nor free Poles in foreign lands, are at the mercy of their jailers and risk at any moment being sent back to the mines of Siberia or executed like their compatriots in the Katyn forest, although Beria does not intend to repeat this "serious error". The Home Affairs Commissar draws up a different plan to use these prisoners. To do this, he has Colonel Zygmund Berling who, on the eve of the evacuation of the Free Polish Army, left his unit to join the Red Army. This desertion is the consequence of the training received by Berling in the Russian academy intended for Polish defectors, the "Villa of Delights", also called "Haven of Bliss", in Malakhovka near Moscow. This training center, created by Beria to prepare executives for Red Poland, is beginning to bear fruit. According to Beria's plan, the recently liberated Poles can choose: either they join a Polish communist army which, under Soviet command, will seize Poland after the German defeat and they will fight their compatriots commanded by General Anders, if that between the first in Poland with the Western powers This training center, created by Beria to prepare executives for Red Poland, is beginning to bear fruit. According to Beria's plan, the recently liberated Poles can choose: either they join a Polish communist army which, under Soviet command, will seize Poland after the German defeat and they will fight their compatriots commanded by General Anders, if that between the first in Poland with the Western powers This training center, created by Beria to prepare executives for Red Poland, is beginning to bear fruit. According to Beria's plan, the recently liberated Poles can choose: either they join a Polish communist army which, under Soviet command, will seize Poland after the German defeat and they will fight their compatriots commanded by General Anders, if that between the first in Poland with the Western powers51 , or else, if this idea does not please them, they will have to return to Siberia.

这个最后通牒的措辞并不如此明确，也不那么直白。贝利亚曲折的政治几乎从来都不是清晰或明显的。在这种情况下，贝利亚决定使用微妙和欺骗性的策略来说服波兰人，他们将为自己的利益而战：解放自己的国家。

This ultimatum is not presented in such clear terms, nor as bluntly. Beria's tortuous politics are almost never clear or obvious. In this case, Beria decides to use subtleties and deceitful stratagems to convince the Poles that they will fight for their own good: the liberation of their country.

尽管贝利亚反对一切形式的民族主义，甚至想将其从祖国格鲁吉亚以及其他高加索国家中根除，但贝利亚决心利用波兰人的民族主义感情。他们以对自己的国家、习俗和天主教信仰的深深尊重而闻名。内政委员以新闻审查员的身份，允许波兰报纸在苏联出版。本周评论题为Nowe Widnokregi（新视野），由一个自称为波兰爱国者联盟的组织出版。在受到贝利亚政府严格审查的民族主义文章和诗歌中，该杂志呼吁读者加入新的波兰分裂科修斯科的行列。科修斯科是18世纪伟大的波兰英雄， 他与俄国人进行了不懈的战斗，并航行到了美国，在那里他成为乔治·华盛顿和托马斯·杰斐逊的私人朋友，象征着波兰人的自由、独立和民主。

Although he is opposed to all forms of nationalism to the point of having wanted to eradicate it from his native country, Georgia, as well as from the other Caucasian nations, Beria is determined to play on the nationalist feelings of the Poles. They are well known for the deep respect they have for their country, their customs and the Catholic faith. The Commissar for Internal Affairs, in his capacity as press censor, gives permission to publish a Polish newspaper in the USSR. This weekly review entitled Nowe Widnokregi (New Horizons), is published by a group calling itself the Union of Polish Patriots. Among nationalist articles and poems, strictly censored by Beria's administration, the magazine calls on its readers to join the ranks of the new Polish division Kosciusko. Kosciusko, a great Polish hero of the 18th century ,  who relentlessly fought the Russians and who sailed to America where he became the personal friend of Georges Washington and Thomas Jefferson symbolizes freedom, independence and democracy for Polish.

这个聪明的计谋完美地成功了。无论如何，如果不想在遥远的北方灭亡，波兰军官和士兵就别无选择，他们对在科修斯科的名义下与德国人作战以解放自己的国家的想法充满了热情。出狱的波兰神父庆祝周日弥撒。波兰人配备了苏联武器和装备，穿着适当的波兰制服，帽子上戴着国徽——白鹰，并由波兰人指挥。然而，他们的总部主要由受过“极乐天堂”洗礼的波兰高级军官控制。经过集中训练，这些部队已经做好了奔赴前线的准备。他们渴望与纳粹作战并报仇。

The clever stratagem succeeded perfectly. Polish officers and soldiers who, in any case, have no choice if they do not want to perish in the far north, overflow with enthusiasm at the idea of ​​fighting the Germans to liberate their country under the auspices of the Kosciusko's name. Polish priests, released from prison, celebrate Sunday mass. The Poles, provided with Soviet arms and equipment, were given proper Polish uniforms, wore the national emblem, the white eagle, on their caps, and were commanded by Poles. Their headquarters, however, is dominated by senior Polish officers indoctrinated in the "Haven of Bliss". After intensive training, these units are ready to go to the front. They are eager to fight the Nazis and get their revenge.

科修斯科师总司令齐格蒙特·柏林上校受邀到克里姆林宫会见斯大林，斯大林将他提升为将军，以表彰他为苏联做出的贡献，让他的部队做好了准备波兰是俄罗斯的卫星国。斯大林在苏联国防委员会全体成员的见证下，授予柏林苏联最高荣誉之一：苏沃洛夫勋章。

The Commander-in-Chief of the Kosciusko Division, Colonel Zygmunt Berling, is invited to the Kremlin to a special audience with Stalin who elevates him to the rank of general, in consideration of his service to the Soviet Union by preparing his troops to make Poland a satellite of Russia. Stalin, in the presence of the entire body of the Soviet Defense Committee, decorated Berling with one of the highest Soviet distinctions: the Order of Suvorov.

但在仪式期间发生了一件最意想不到的事情。这是整个苏联历史上、甚至克里姆林宫内从未发生过的事件。波兰叛徒伯林恳求斯大林大元帅不要授予他这一命令。

But a most unexpected event takes place during the ceremony. This is an incident that has never happened before in the entire history of the Soviet Union or even within the walls of the Kremlin. The Polish traitor Berling begs Generalissimo Stalin not to award him the order.

脸上露出了极大的惊愕。伯林向斯大林同志解释说，这种勋章可能会激怒科修斯科师的士兵，他们被如此巧妙地欺骗了。苏沃洛夫是叶卡捷琳娜大帝时代最有才华的俄罗斯元帅之一，他与科修斯科指挥的波兰军队作战，并因在华沙郊区屠杀波兰妇女和儿童而闻名。俄罗斯科修斯科师的总司令被授予苏沃洛夫这个名字，即使不是讽刺，也是值得怀疑的。

A great consternation is marked on the faces. Berling explains to Comrade Stalin that this decoration might irritate the men of Kosciusko's division, who have been so adroitly deceived. Suvorov, one of the most gifted Russian marshals of the time of Catherine the Great, fought the Polish armies commanded by Kosciusko and became famous for massacring Polish women and children in the suburbs of Warsaw. It would be suspicious, if not ironic, for a commander-in-chief of the Kosciusko Division in Russia to be decorated with the name Suvorov.

一度笼罩仪式的惊愕气氛消散了。所有苏联政要，包括斯大林，都笑得像只有俄罗斯人才能笑的那样。刚刚晋升的柏林将军获得了同等但更合适的级别的勋章。然后，一行人前往毗邻的房间，专门用于不太正式的招待会，里面有鱼子酱和伏特加。

The atmosphere of consternation that had clouded the ceremony for a moment dissipates. All the Soviet dignitaries, including Stalin, laugh as only Russians can. General Berling, who has just been promoted, receives an order of an equivalent but more suitable class. The group then goes to an adjoining room, reserved for less formal receptions, with caviar and vodka.

柏林的部队隶属于白俄罗斯第一方面军司令康斯坦丁·罗科索夫斯基元帅的苏联军团，不久就占领了战场。

Berling's troops, attached to the Soviet regiments of Marshal Konstantin Rokossovski, commander of the first Belarusian front, soon after gained the battlefield.

战争即将结束。纳粹在欧洲、意大利、北非、托布鲁克、近东、阿拉曼、大西洋和太平洋，甚至在他们自己的国家，柏林、慕尼黑、法兰克福和汉堡都被美国人轰炸过。和英国空军。

The war is coming to an end. The Nazis are beaten in Europe, Italy, as well as in North Africa, Tobruk, the Near East, El-Alamein, the Atlantic and the Pacific, and even in their own country where Berlin, Munich , Frankfurt and Hamburg are bombed by American and British air forces.

在仍被德国人占领的波兰首都，抵抗军已准备好崛起。这支4万多人的军队由训练有素的官兵组成，装备有英国空投或通过英吉利海峡和波罗的海走私的武器。他们还拥有游击队在夜间袭击纳粹运输工具、驻军和军火库时缴获的德国步枪和机枪。罗科索夫斯基的军队将纳粹赶回东部。很明显，几周后红军将逼近华沙。然而，令人担心的是，如果德国军队不费一枪一弹就放弃了波兰首都，波兰人就会感觉到新的危险，将像五年前那样与布尔什维克作战。当斯大林是希特勒的盟友时。他们将得到罗科索夫斯基部队后面科修斯科团的波兰人的支持。他们显然没有获胜的机会，但波兰人享有堂吉诃德的美誉，在斯大林和贝利亚看来，他们无论何时何地都是麻烦制造者。在被击败之前，他们可以与苏联作战几周，并在不知不觉中帮助德国。

In the Polish capital still occupied by the Germans, the Resistance army is ready to rise. This army of more than 40,000 men is made up of well-trained officers and soldiers equipped with British weapons delivered by airdrops or smuggled through the English Channel and the Baltic. They also have German rifles and machine guns captured during night raids by partisans on Nazi transports, garrisons and arsenals. Rokossovski's army pushes the Nazis back to the east. It is clear that in a few weeks the Reds will approach Warsaw. It is to be feared, however, that in the event that the German forces abandon the Polish capital without firing a shot, the Poles, sensing a new danger, will fight the Bolsheviks as they did five years earlier, when Stalin was Hitler's ally. They would be supported by Poles from the Kosciusko regiments behind Rokossovski's troops. They would obviously have no chance of winning, but the Poles have a reputation as Don Quixote who, in the opinion of Stalin and Beria, have always and everywhere been troublemakers. Before being defeated, they could fight the USSR for a few weeks and unwittingly help Germany.

必须不惜一切代价避免这种情况。在国防委员会的一次会议上，贝利亚提议煽动波兰人起义反抗德国人，让祖国军被他们打死歼灭。随后，因镇压波兰民族运动而流血的纳粹军队将被削弱，很容易被红军击败。这一计将使俄罗斯人获得双重成功：他们将轻松战胜波兰领土上的纳粹分子，并摆脱与他们敌对的波兰本土军队。

This must be avoided at all costs. At a meeting of the defense committee, Beria proposes to instigate a Polish uprising against the Germans so that the Home Army will be beaten to death and annihilated by them. Subsequently, the Nazi troops, bled by the repression of the Polish national movement, will be weakened and can be easily defeated by the Red Army. This stratagem would allow the Russians to achieve a double success: they would obtain an easy victory over the Nazis in Polish territory and they would get rid of the Polish Home Army which is hostile to them.
